repo.name: perf-triage
repo.description: Tools used for triaging performance bugs.

issue.title: Incorrectly combining data for chrome/chromium for certain subtests
issue.body:
For example:
https://arewefastyet.com/win10/benchmarks/raptor-desktop-jetstream2?numDays=60
https://arewefastyet.com/win10/benchmarks/raptor-desktop-speedometer?numDays=60

The first graph (total benchmark score) is okay and has separate data points for chrome and chromium. For the sub tests, we get a single data point for both. It looks like the data is incorrectly combined somewhere.

comment.body: @beatrice-acasandrei is going to look into this when she's back from PTO next week.

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,4 @@
+The severity field for this bug is set to {{ extra[bugid]["severity"] }}. However, the `Performance Impact` field flags this bug as having a high impact on the performance.
+:{{ nickname }}, could you consider increasing the severity of this performance-impacting bug?
comment.body: I like @marco-c's suggestion about requesting retriage.

pull_request.title: Add a tool to suggest increasing the severity of performance-impacting bugs
pull_request.body:
<!---
Please describe why and what this Pull Request is doing
-->

Resolves #1709

# Autonag wiki page
```wiki
{{AutonagRule
  | Rule name = Severity of performance impacting bugs
  | Purpose   = Consistency and help getting traction on bugs with a high impact on performance
  | Action    = Needinfo the assignee or the triage owner (if not assigned) to increase the severity
  | Source    = severity_high_performance_impact.py 
}}
```


## Checklist

<!---
The following should be done (and marked as completed) when applicable. Please do not remove inapplicable items.
-->

- [ ] Type annotations added to new functions
- [ ] Docs added to functions touched in main classes
- [x] Dry-run produced the expected results
- [ ] The [`to-be-announced`](https://github.com/mozilla/relman-auto-nag/labels/to-be-announced) tag added if this is worth announcing

labels.name: to-be-announced
labels.description: Improvements to be announced: send to dev-platform, firefox-dev and add to EE newsletter

repo.name: relman-auto-nag
repo.description: A Mozilla release management tool to sent reminders to Firefox developers and improve Bugzilla metadata

repo.name: relman-auto-nag
repo.description: A Mozilla release management tool to send reminders to Firefox developers and improve Bugzilla metadata

issue.title: Performance Tab - Display sheriffed results on top, unsheriffed on the bottom

comment.body: In this case it is just `fetch_content` that doesn't alert? I'm fine with this as it is, and don't want to hold up landing it, but I do wonder if we should make it clear that some results don't alert. I'm thinking we could have two separate tables, or perhaps hide results that don't alert by default until a user expands them. What do you think? Possibly a good conversation for the next projects meeting.

issue.title: Performance Tab - Display sheriffed results on top, unsheriffed on the bottom

comment.body: Hey @beatrice-acasandrei, do you have a screenshot to show how this looks?

issue.title: FXP-2435 Disable P2 perf tests
issue.body: Removing Google Pixel 2 from AWFY as part of FXP-2435

comment.body:
> All other tasks related to disabling the P2 perftests are complete as part of [this patch](https://phabricator.services.mozilla.com/D159375) which is going to land soon. Looks like we can merge the Performance Dashboard changes.

Thanks Alex. The historical data may be valuable for a while, let's set a reminder for us to merge this in 4 weeks.

issue.title: Provide an option to see the how the calculator works
issue.body: We've received feedback that it's not clear how the calculator arrives at the various impact levels. We could add a way to peek under the hood and see how each option contributes to the score. This will help users to provide more specific feedback when they see something unexpected.

issue.title: Provide an option to see the how the calculator works
issue.body: We've received feedback that it's not clear how the calculator arrives at the various impact levels. We could add a way to peek under the hood and see how each option contributes to the score. This will help users to provide more specific feedback when they see something unexpected.

comment.body: I've added a debug toggle to show how each option impacts the score.

issue.title: Provide an option to see the how the calculator works
issue.body: We've received feedback that it's not clear how the calculator arrives at the various impact levels. We could add a way to peek under the hood and see how each option contributes to the score. This will help users to provide more specific feedback when they see something unexpected.
